Spanish Verb Directory

Verbs for beginners with conjugation tables, example phrases, and proverbs

Spanish

Spanish is the second most popular language in the United States and the official language of over 20 countries. Learning Spanish will open up a world of opportunities for you. This directory is a collection of resources to help you learn Spanish verbs. It is a work in progress and will be updated occasionally. If you have any suggestions for additions or improvements, please let me know.

Code 
library(tidyverse)
library(gt)

df = read_csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/ghidinelli/fred-jehle-spanish-verbs/master/jehle_verb_database.csv")

my_gt_theme <- function(gt_object, ...) {
  
  stopifnot("'gt_object' must be a 'gt_tbl', have you accidentally passed raw data?" = "gt_tbl" %in% class(gt_object))
  
  tab_out <- gt_object %>%
    # Fonts
    opt_table_font(
      font = list(
        google_font("Noto Sans"), 
        google_font("Source Sans Pro"),
        default_fonts()
      )
    ) %>%
    
    # Cell styles from both themes
    tab_style(
      style = cell_borders(
        sides = "top", color = "white", weight = px(0)),
      locations = cells_body(rows = ifelse(nrow(gt_object[["_data"]]) > 0, 1, NA))) %>%
    tab_style(
      style = cell_text(color = "#005689", size = px(22), weight = 700),
      locations = list(cells_title(groups = "title"))) %>%
    tab_style(
      style = cell_text(color = "#545454", font = google_font("Source Sans Pro"), transform = "uppercase"),
      locations = cells_column_labels(everything())) %>%
    tab_style(
      style = cell_text(font = google_font("Libre Franklin"), weight = 800),
      locations = cells_title(groups = "title")) %>%
    tab_style(
      style = cell_text(font = google_font("Source Sans Pro"), weight = 400),
      locations = cells_body()) %>%
    
    # Table options combining elements of both themes
    tab_options(
      # Table-wide settings
      table.background.color = "white",
      table.font.size = 16,
      
      # Table border settings
      table.border.top.style = "none",
      table.border.top.width = px(1),
      table.border.top.color = "#40c5ff",
      table.border.bottom.width = px(3),
      table.border.bottom.color = "white",
      
      # Column label settings
      column_labels.background.color = "#f6f6f6",
      column_labels.font.weight = "bold",
      column_labels.border.top.style = "none",
      column_labels.border.bottom.style = "none",
      column_labels.border.bottom.width = 1,
      column_labels.border.bottom.color = "#334422",
      
      # Data row settings
      row.striping.include_table_body = TRUE,
      row.striping.background_color = "#ececec",
      data_row.padding = px(6), # Average of both themes
      
      # Row group settings
      row_group.font.weight = "800",
      
      # Heading settings
      heading.align = "left",
      heading.border.bottom.style = "none",
      
      # Table body border settings
      table_body.border.top.style = "none",
      
      # Source notes settings
      source_notes.font.size = 12,
      
    )
  
  return(tab_out)
}

create_conjugation_table <- function(verb_infinitive) {
  
  verb_order = c("Presente", 
                 "Imperfecto", 
                 "Pret√©rito", 
                 "Futuro", 
                 "Condicional", 
                 "Presente perfecto",
                 "Pluscuamperfecto",
                 "Pret√©rito anterior",
                 "Futuro perfecto",
                 "Condicional perfecto")
  
  verb_df <- df %>%
    filter(infinitive == verb_infinitive)
  
  infinitive = verb_df %>% pull(infinitive) %>% .[1] 
  english_infinitive = verb_df %>% pull(infinitive_english) %>% .[1] %>% str_to_title
  gerund = verb_df %>% pull(gerund) %>% .[1] 
  past_participle = verb_df %>% pull(pastparticiple) %>% .[1] 
  
  verb_table <- verb_df %>%
    select(-c(tense_english, 
              infinitive, 
              infinitive_english, 
              verb_english,
              # mood, 
              mood_english,
              gerund, 
              gerund_english, 
              pastparticiple, 
              pastparticiple_english
              )) %>%
    mutate(
      temp_form_2p = form_2p,
      form_2p = ifelse(mood %in% c("Imperativo Afirmativo","Imperativo Negativo"), form_3s, form_2p),
      form_3s = ifelse(mood %in% c("Imperativo Afirmativo","Imperativo Negativo"), temp_form_2p, form_3s),
      form_1p = ifelse(is.na(form_1p), paste0(form_3s, "mos"), form_1p),
      form_1s = ifelse(is.na(form_1s), " - ", form_1s)
    ) %>%
    select(-temp_form_2p) %>% 
    mutate(tense = factor(tense, levels = verb_order)) %>% 
    arrange(tense) %>% 
    group_by(mood) %>% 
    gt() %>%
    tab_header(
      title = paste("Conjugation of",infinitive),
      subtitle = md(glue::glue(sprintf("English: *{english_infinitive}*\n
                                     Gerundio: *{gerund}*\n
                                     Pasado Participio: *{past_participle}*")))) %>%
    cols_label(
      tense = "Tense",
      # verb_english = "English",
      form_1s = "Yo",
      form_2s = "T√∫",
      form_3s = "√âl/Ella/Usted",
      form_1p = "Nosotros",
      form_2p = "Vosotros",
      form_3p = "Ellos/Ellas/Ustedes"
    ) %>% 
    cols_align(
      align = c("right"),
      columns = everything()
    ) %>% 
    cols_align(
      align = c("left"),
      columns = tense
    ) %>% 
    my_gt_theme()

  return(verb_table)
}

to be

Ser is one of the most important irregular verbs for beginning students. It is used in a vast number of idiomatic expressions and everyday situations. Be careful when you need to choose between ser and estar. You should study the special rules for the use of estar. They‚Äôre listed with that verb.

to be

When to use estar vs ser

Health:

  • ¬øC√≥mo est√° Ud.? How are you?
  • Estoy bien. I am well.
  • Estoy enfermo (enferma). I am sick.

Location: persons, places, things

  • Estoy en la sala de clase. I am in the classroom.
  • La escuela est√° lejos. The school is far.
  • Barcelona est√° en Espa√±a. Barcelona is (located) in Spain.
  • Los libros est√°n en la mesa. The books are on the table.

State or condition: persons

  • Estoy contento (contenta). I am happy.
  • Los alumnos est√°n cansados. (Las alumnas est√°n cansadas.) The students are tired.
  • Mar√≠a est√° triste hoy. Mary is sad today.
  • Estoy listo (lista). I am ready.
  • Estoy p√°lido (p√°lida). I am pale.
  • Estoy ocupado (ocupada). I am busy.
  • Estoy seguro (segura). I am sure.
  • Este hombre est√° vivo. This man is alive.
  • Ese hombre est√° muerto. That man is dead.
  • Este hombre est√° borracho. This man is drunk.

To form the progressive present of a verb:

use the present tense of estar + the present participle of the main verb

  • Estoy estudiando en mi cuarto y no puedo salir esta noche.
    • I am studying in my room and I cannot go out tonight.

To form the progressive past of a verb:

use the imperfect tense of estar + the present participle of the main verb:

  • Mi hermano estaba leyendo cuando (yo) entr√© en el cuarto.
    • My brother was reading when I entered (came into) the room.

to have

can, to be able to

Poder is a very useful verb for a beginning student. You can use it in a vast number of idiomatic expressions and everyday situations.

Poder means can in the sense of ability:

  • No puedo ayudarle; lo siento
    • I cannot (am unable to) help you; I‚Äôm sorry.

In the preterit tense poder has the special meaning of succeeded:

  • Despu√©s de algunos minutos, Juan pudo abrir la puerta
    • After a few minutes, John succeeded in opening the door.

Formulas with hacer

¬øCu√°nto tiempo hace que + present tense‚Ä¶?

  1. Use this formula when you want to ask How long + the present perfect tense in English:
    • ¬øCu√°nto tiempo hace que Ud. estudia espa√±ol?
    • How long have you been studying Spanish?
  2. When this formula is used, you generally expect the person to tell you how long a time it has been, e.g., one year, two months, a few minutes.
  3. This is used when the action began at some time in the past and continues up to the present moment. That is why you must use the present tense of the verb‚Äîthe action of studying, waiting, etc., is still going on at the present.

¬øHace + length of time + que + present tense

  1. This formula is the usual answer to the question ¬øCu√°nto tiempo hace que + present tense‚Ä¶?
  2. Since the question is asked in terms of how long, the usual answer is in terms of time: a year, two years, a few days, months, minutes, etc.:
    • Hace tres a√±os que estudio espa√±ol.
    • I have been studying Spanish for three years.
  3. The same formula is used if you want to ask how many weeks, how many months, how many minutes, etc.:
    • ¬øCu√°ntos a√±os hace que Ud. estudia espa√±ol?
    • How many years have you been studying Spanish?

¬øDesde cu√°ndo + present tense‚Ä¶?
- ¬øDesde cu√°ndo estudia Ud. espa√±ol?
- How long have you been studying Spanish?

Present tense + desde hace + length of time
- Estudio espa√±ol desde hace tres a√±os.
- I have been studying Spanish for three years.

to go

Ir and irse are a very important pair of verbs for a beginning student. In the following examples, note the difference in meaning between ir and the creflexive form irse.

Use ir when you simply mean to go:

  • Voy al cine
    • I am going to the movies.

Use irse when you mean to leave in the sense of to go away:

  • Mis padres se fueron al campo para visitar a mis abuelos
    • My parents left for (went away to) the country to visit my grandparents.

to have (as an auxiliary, helping verb to form the compound tenses)

Haber is an essential verb for beginning students of Spanish. You need to be able to conjugate haber in order to form the compound tenses. In other words, if you can conjugate haber in the simple tenses, you can form any other verb in the compound tenses! The verb haber is used as an auxiliary (helping) verb as follows:

Compound tenses Example (in the 1st person sing.)

  • Present Perfect (or Perfect) Indicative
    • he hablado (I have spoken)
  • Pluperfect (or Past Perfect) Indicative
    • hab√≠a hablado (I had spoken)
  • Preterit Perfect (or Past Anterior)
    • hube hablado (I had spoken)
  • Future Perfect (or Future Anterior)
    • habr√© hablado (I will have spoken)
  • Conditional Perfect
    • habr√≠a hablado (I would have spoken)
  • Present Perfect (or Past) Subjunctive
    • haya hablado (I may have spoken)
  • Pluperfect (or Past Perfect) Subjunctive
    • hubiera hablado or hubiese hablado (I might have spoken)

The verb haber is also used to form: - the perfect (or past) infinitive: haber hablado (to have spoken). As you can see, this is formed by using the infinitive form of haber + the past participle of the main verb.

  • the perfect participle: habiendo hablado (having spoken). This is formed by using the present participle of haber + the past participle of the main verb.

The verb haber + de + inf. is equivalent to the English use of ‚Äúto be supposed to‚Ä¶‚Äù or ‚Äúto be to‚Ä¶‚Äù

  • Mar√≠a ha de traer un pastel, yo he de traer el helado, y mis amigos han de traer las bebidas
    • Mary is supposed to bring a cake, I am supposed to bring the ice cream, and my friends are supposed to bring the drinks.
Note

Note on hay and hay que + inf.

The word hay is not a verb. You might look at it as an impersonal irregular form of haber. Actually, the word is composed of ha + the archaic y, meaning there. It is generally seen as an adverbial expression because it points out that something or someone ‚Äúis there.‚Äù Its English equivalent is There is‚Ä¶ or There are‚Ä¶

  • For example: Hay muchos libros en la mesa/There are many books on the table; Hay veinte alumnos en esta clase/There are twenty students in this class.

Hay que + inf. is an impersonal expression that denotes an obligation and it is commonly translated into English as: One must‚Ä¶ or It is necessary to‚Ä¶

  • Examples: Hay que estudiar para aprender/It is necessary to study in order to learn; Hay que comer para vivir/One must eat in order to live.

library(tidyverse)
library(gt)

df = read_csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/ghidinelli/fred-jehle-spanish-verbs/master/jehle_verb_database.csv")

add_reflexive <- function(df, verb) {
  
  reflexive_df <- df %>%
    filter(infinitive == verb) %>%
    mutate(infinitive = paste0(infinitive, "se")) %>%
    mutate(
      across(c(form_1s, form_2s, form_3s, form_1p, form_2p, form_3p),
             ~ if_else(mood %in% c("Indicativo", "Subjuntivo"), 
                       paste0(str_replace_all(.x, pattern = "^(me|te|se|nos|os)?", replacement = ""), " ", .x),
                       .x),
             .names = "form_{.col}"),
      across(c(form_2s, form_3s, form_1p, form_2p, form_3p),
             ~ if_else(mood == "Imperativo Afirmativo", 
                       paste0(.x," ", str_replace_all(.x, pattern = "^(me|te|se|nos|os)?", replacement = "")),
                       .x),
             .names = "form_{.col}"),
      across(c(form_2s, form_3s, form_1p, form_2p, form_3p),
             ~ if_else(mood == "Imperativo Negativo", 
                       paste(str_split(.x, " ")[[1]][1], 
                            str_replace_all(.x, pattern = "^(me|te|se|nos|os)?", replacement = ""), 
                            str_split(.x, " ")[[1]][2]),
                       .x),
             .names = "form_{.col}")
    )
  
  df %>% bind_rows(reflexive_df)
}

my_gt_theme <- function(gt_object, ...) {
  
  stopifnot("'gt_object' must be a 'gt_tbl', have you accidentally passed raw data?" = "gt_tbl" %in% class(gt_object))
  
  tab_out <- gt_object %>%
    # Fonts
    opt_table_font(
      font = list(
        google_font("Noto Sans"), 
        google_font("Source Sans Pro"),
        default_fonts()
      )
    ) %>%
    
    # Cell styles from both themes
    tab_style(
      style = cell_borders(
        sides = "top", color = "white", weight = px(0)),
      locations = cells_body(rows = ifelse(nrow(gt_object[["_data"]]) > 0, 1, NA))) %>%
    tab_style(
      style = cell_text(color = "#005689", size = px(22), weight = 700),
      locations = list(cells_title(groups = "title"))) %>%
    tab_style(
      style = cell_text(color = "#545454", font = google_font("Source Sans Pro"), transform = "uppercase"),
      locations = cells_column_labels(everything())) %>%
    tab_style(
      style = cell_text(font = google_font("Libre Franklin"), weight = 800),
      locations = cells_title(groups = "title")) %>%
    tab_style(
      style = cell_text(font = google_font("Source Sans Pro"), weight = 400),
      locations = cells_body()) %>%
    
    # Table options combining elements of both themes
    tab_options(
      # Table-wide settings
      table.background.color = "white",
      table.font.size = 16,
      
      # Table border settings
      table.border.top.style = "none",
      table.border.top.width = px(1),
      table.border.top.color = "#40c5ff",
      table.border.bottom.width = px(3),
      table.border.bottom.color = "white",
      
      # Column label settings
      column_labels.background.color = "#f6f6f6",
      column_labels.font.weight = "bold",
      column_labels.border.top.style = "none",
      column_labels.border.bottom.style = "none",
      column_labels.border.bottom.width = 1,
      column_labels.border.bottom.color = "#334422",
      
      # Data row settings
      row.striping.include_table_body = TRUE,
      row.striping.background_color = "#ececec",
      data_row.padding = px(6), # Average of both themes
      
      # Row group settings
      row_group.font.weight = "800",
      
      # Heading settings
      heading.align = "left",
      heading.border.bottom.style = "none",
      
      # Table body border settings
      table_body.border.top.style = "none",
      
      # Source notes settings
      source_notes.font.size = 12,
      
    )
  
  return(tab_out)
}

create_conjugation_table <- function(verb_infinitive) {
  
  verb_order = c("Presente", 
                 "Imperfecto", 
                 "Pret√©rito", 
                 "Futuro", 
                 "Condicional", 
                 "Presente perfecto",
                 "Pluscuamperfecto",
                 "Pret√©rito anterior",
                 "Futuro perfecto",
                 "Condicional perfecto")
  
  verb_df <- df %>%
    filter(infinitive == verb_infinitive)
  
  infinitive = verb_df %>% pull(infinitive) %>% .[1] 
  english_infinitive = verb_df %>% pull(infinitive_english) %>% .[1] %>% str_to_title
  gerund = verb_df %>% pull(gerund) %>% .[1] 
  past_participle = verb_df %>% pull(pastparticiple) %>% .[1] 
  
  verb_table <- verb_df %>%
    mutate(
      temp_form_2p = form_2p,
      form_2p = ifelse(mood %in% c("Imperativo Afirmativo","Imperativo Negativo"), form_3s, form_2p),
      form_3s = ifelse(mood %in% c("Imperativo Afirmativo","Imperativo Negativo"), temp_form_2p, form_3s),
      form_1p = ifelse(is.na(form_1p), paste0(form_3s, "mos"), form_1p),
      form_1s = ifelse(is.na(form_1s), " - ", form_1s)) %>%
    select(-c(tense_english, 
              infinitive, 
              infinitive_english, 
              verb_english,
              # mood, 
              mood_english,
              gerund, 
              gerund_english, 
              pastparticiple, 
              pastparticiple_english,
              temp_form_2p
              )) %>%
    mutate(tense = factor(tense, levels = verb_order)) %>% 
    arrange(tense) %>% 
    group_by(mood) %>% 
    gt() %>%
    tab_header(
      title = paste("Conjugation of",infinitive),
      subtitle = md(glue::glue(sprintf("English: *{english_infinitive}*\n
                                     Gerundio: *{gerund}*\n
                                     Pasado Participio: *{past_participle}*")))) %>%
    cols_label(
      tense = "Tense",
      # verb_english = "English",
      form_1s = "Yo",
      form_2s = "T√∫",
      form_3s = "√âl/Ella/Usted",
      form_1p = "Nosotros",
      form_2p = "Vosotros",
      form_3p = "Ellos/Ellas/Ustedes"
    ) %>% 
    cols_align(
      align = c("right"),
      columns = everything()
    ) %>% 
    cols_align(
      align = c("left"),
      columns = tense
    ) %>% 
    my_gt_theme()

  return(verb_table)
}

to owe, must, ought

Deber is a verb that you ought to know! It is a regular -er verb that is used in a great number of everyday expressions and situations.

Generally speaking, use deber when you want to express a moral obligation, something you ought to do, but that you may or may not actually do:

  • Debo estudiar esta noche pero estoy cansado y no me siento bien.
    • I ought to study tonight, but I am tired and I do not feel well.

In general, deber de + inf. is used to express a supposition, something that is probable:

  • La se√±ora G√≥mez debe de estar enferma porque sale de casa raramente.
    • Mrs. G√≥mez must be sick (is probably sick) because she rarely goes out of the house

Imperativo
- singular ¬°Que guste!
- plural ¬°Que gusten!

Gustar is an essential regular -ar verb for beginning students of Spanish. It is used in many everyday expressions and situations. Please note that this verb is commonly used in the third person singular or plural, as in the examples below.

  • (a) Essentially, the verb gustar means to be pleasing to‚Ä¶

  • (b) In English, we say, for example, I like ice cream. In Spanish, we say Me gusta el helado; that is to say, ‚ÄúIce cream is pleasing to me (Literally: To me, ice cream is pleasing).‚Äù

  • (c) In English, the thing that you like is the direct object. In Spanish, the thing that you like is the subject. Also, in Spanish, the person who likes the thing is the indirect object: to me, to you, etc. For example: ‚ÄúA Roberto le gusta el helado/Robert likes ice cream (Literally: To Robert, ice cream is pleasing to him).‚Äù

  • (d) In Spanish, therefore, the verb gustar is used in the third person, either in the singular or plural, when you talk about something that you like‚Äî something that is pleasing to you. Therefore, the verb form must agree with the subject; if the thing that is liked is singular, the verb is third person singular: Me gusta el caf√©/I like coffee. If the thing that is liked is plural, the verb gustar is third person plural: ‚ÄúMe gustan el caf√© y la leche/I like coffee and milk (Literally: Coffee and milk are pleasing to me).‚Äù

  • (e) When you mention the person or the persons who like something, you must use the preposition a in front of the person. You must also use the indirect object pronoun that is associated with the person: A los muchachos y a las muchachas les gusta jugar/Boys and girls like to play. (Literally: To boys and girls, to play is pleasing to them.)

Example Phrases

  • Me gusta el caf√©.
    • I like coffee.
  • Me gusta leer.
    • I like to read.
  • Te gusta leer.
    • You (familiar) like to read.
  • Me gustan la leche y el caf√©.
    • I like milk and coffee.
  • A Mar√≠a le gustan los dulces.
    • Mary likes candy.
  • A Jos√© y a Elena les gustan los deportes.
    • Joseph and Helen like sports.
  • Nos gustan mucho las pel√≠culas polic√≠acas.
    • We like detective movies very much.
  • Me gustar√≠a un pastel.
    • I would like a pastry.
  • A Felipe le gusta el helado.
    • Philip likes ice cream.
  • A las chicas les gust√≥ la pel√≠cula.
    • The girls liked the movie.
  • Nos gust√≥ el cuento.
    • We liked the story.
  • A mi amigo le gustaron los chocolates.
    • My friend liked the chocolates.

    • taste, pleasure, liking

to think

We think that pensar is a very useful verb for you to learn. It is used in a great number of idiomatic expressions and everyday situations. Pay attention to the stem change in Tenses 1 and 6 and in the imperative mood.

Pensar is used with the preposition de when you ask someone what he/she thinks of someone or something, i.e., when you ask for someone‚Äôs opinion:

  • ¬øQu√© piensa Ud. de este libro?
    • What do you think of this book?
  • Pienso que es bueno
    • I think that it is good.

Pensar is used with the preposition en when you ask someone what or whom he/she is thinking about:

  • Miguel, no hablas mucho; ¬øen qu√© piensas?
    • Michael, you are not talking much; what are you thinking of? (of what are you thinking?);
  • Pienso en las vacaciones de verano
    • I‚Äôm thinking of summer vacation.

to know, to know how

Saber is a very useful irregular verb for you to know. It is used in a great number of idiomatic expressions and everyday situations. Don‚Äôt confuse saber with conocer

Generally speaking, saber means to know a fact, to know something thoroughly:

  • ¬øSabe Ud. qu√© hora es?/Do you know what time it is?
  • ¬øSabe Ud. la lecci√≥n?/Do you know the lesson?

When you use saber + inf., it means to know how:

  • ¬øSabe Ud. nadar?/Do you know how to swim?
  • S√≠, (yo) s√© nadar/Yes, I know how to swim.

In the preterit tense, saber means to find out:

  • ¬øLo sabe Ud.?/Do you know it?
  • S√≠, lo supe ayer/Yes, I found it out yesterday.

Conocer is a verb that you should know! Pay special attention to the spelling change from c to zc before a or o. Conocer is useful in numerous everyday expressions and situations

Be careful when choosing between conocer and saber, which also means to know.

  • (a) Generally speaking, conocer means to know in the sense of being acquainted with a person, a place, or a thing:
    • ¬øConoce Ud. a Mar√≠a?
      Do you know Mary?
    • ¬øConoce Ud. bien los Estados Unidos?
      Do you know the United States well?
    • ¬øConoce Ud. este libro?
      Do you know this book? (Are you acquainted with this book?)

In the preterit tense, conocer means met in the sense of first met, first became acquainted with someone: - ¬øConoce Ud. a Elena?
Do you know Helen? - S√≠, (yo) la conoc√≠ anoche en casa de un amigo m√≠o.
Yes, I met her (for the first time) last night at the home of one of my friends.

Generally speaking, saber means to know a fact, to know something thoroughly: - ¬øSabe Ud. qu√© hora es?
Do you know what time it is?
(See saber for further examples.)

to go out, to leave

Salir is a very useful irregular verb for you to learn. It is used in a great number of idiomatic expressions and everyday situations.

Be careful not to confuse salir and dejar. Use salir de when you mean to leave in the sense of to go out of (a place): > El alumno sali√≥ de la sala de clase.
> The pupil left the classroom.

The Spanish Idiomatic Expression

acabar de + inf. in Spanish is translated to English as to have just + past participle.

Present Indicative:

When you use acabar in the present tense, it indicates that the action of the main verb (+ inf.) has just occurred now in the present. In English, we express this using have just + the past participle of the main verb.

Examples:

  • Mar√≠a acaba de llegar.
    • Mary has just arrived.
  • Acabo de comer.
    • I have just eaten.
  • Acabamos de terminar la lecci√≥n.
    • We have just finished the lesson.

Imperfect Indicative:

When using acabar in the imperfect indicative, it denotes that the action of the main verb (+ inf.) had occurred at some past time when another action transpired. In English, this is articulated using had just + the past participle of the main verb.

Examples:

  • Mar√≠a acababa de llegar.
    • Mary had just arrived.
  • Yo acababa de comer.
    • I had just eaten.
  • Acab√°bamos de terminar la lecci√≥n.
    • We had just finished the lesson.

Proverbio

  • Bien est√° lo que bien acaba.
    • All‚Äôs well that ends well.

Dichos

  • el acabamiento
    • completion
  • acabar con
    • to put an end to
  • acabar en
    • to end in
  • acabar por
    • to end by, to ‚Ä¶ finally
  • acabado, acabada
    • finished
Note

Note: When acabar is used in the imperfect indicative + inf. (of the main verb being expressed), the verb in the other clause is typically in the preterit.
Example:
Acab√°bamos de entrar cuando el tel√©fono son√≥.
We had just entered the house when the telephone rang.
